areca Chewing areca nuts ~kanu Vanikoro is, with Tikopia, the world's easternmost place where the chewing of areca nuts is a traditional practice. People go in the forest to pick (~ali) areca nuts (buioe), and pinch (~kidi) betel leaves (puluko). The two elements are then mixed with lime (awo), and chewed together (~kanu) until feeling dizzy ( ~avo).

Serves to introduce a new participant in a situation, often an instrument or a theme, even when no actual ‘grabbing’ event is referred to. <ÉtiquetteSémantique langue="eng">esp</ÉtiquetteSémantique> <Étiquette> syntaxe often first verb in serialisation </Étiquette>

pound bamboos on the ground, to make music [ ~woi okoro]

Définition.ReprésentationDeTexte: pound heavy bamboos vertically and repeatedly onto the ground, to mark bass rhythms while singing

Exemple.ReprésentationDeTexte: Kape ba-woi okoro, bai-oburo ne mane.
We shall pound the bamboos and sing songs, in the dancing area.

Définition.ReprésentationDeTexte: welcome ‹traveller› upon their arrival, . on the beach

Exemple.ReprésentationDeTexte: Teliki iadapa li-abu li-ka, li-wokobe da po la-sai kuo.
The chiefs came down and welcomed them as they landed their canoe (on the beach).

Définition.ReprésentationDeTexte: Red Ginger, k.o. plant with bright red flowers (Zingiberaceae)

Dictionnaire.EntréeLexicale:
~womanga (i·)womaŋa
vt
fidim nourrir feed
give food to, feed ‹man, animal›
A-ko bwara kape u-e namuko, ia vana a-womanga dapa nga ponu! You thought you would eat these fish, but actually you're only feeding them!
pe li-womanga
phr
tame, domestic (one) which is fed
Vao, we pe li-womanga? Is (this animal) wild, or tame?
antonyme vao
<Étymologie> <Étymon> *maŋan POc </Étymon> </Étymologie>

Définition.ReprésentationDeTexte: panne: poutre horizontale de la charpente, située à mi-hauteur du toit, entre la sablière et la poutre faîtière (pumene)
purlin: horizontal beam in the roof structure, situated half way up, between the stringpiece and the ridge beam (pumene)

Exemple.ReprésentationDeTexte: Dapa noma, li-ovei pe li-loko uie woubo pe le-vei bavede peini.
People before used to weave sails out of pandanus leaves.

Note.ReprésentationDeTexte: corresponds to /na-gavag/ in Mwotlap!! not to /nēgēy/ or /nōyōpdēge/

Exemple.ReprésentationDeTexte: wowo iero
the top of the Casuarina tree
Dapa kula ka li-bu ne revo, dapa kula li-wowo li-koie ne kulumoe.
Some of them died in the sea, some others swam till they reached the island.
Li-wowo ñe viko iadapa.
They swam with their treasures.
None pon, ini ñepe pe i-ta, pe li-wowo tae.
This kind of yam grows on its own, it is not planted.
Emel' iote i-le i-wowo revo i-ka i-sabisi se awene.
A woman went to draw saltwater, and brought it back to pour it above the oven.
Ni-wowo revo i-ke mina lema kuo.
I'm bailing out the (sea) water from inside the canoe.
